Award.AwardTitle: STEP - Center for Achievement, Retention and Student Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is a comprehensive program, under the Center for Achievement, Retention and Student Success (CARSS), that facilitates the successful transition and integration of incoming high school graduates and community college transfers. It involves collaborations between the Departments of Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics, and leverages existing support mechanisms. Project goals include a 40% to 50% increase in the 4-year graduation rates of a cohort of freshman with declared STEM majors, a 40% to 50% increase in the 2-3 year graduation rates of transfer students entering the University in their junior year, and a 50% increase in the number of STEM graduates from historically underserved populations. Efforts to sustain CARSS through institutional commitments include the dedication of 1500 sq. ft. of space for CARSS advising and mentoring services for students in STEM fields; the continuation of the CARSS Coordinator Staff line; continued funding support for the Peer Tutors and Mentors at the conclusion of the funding period; and the continued provision of in-kind services such as the use of Academic Support Services personnel and resources after the funding period has ended. The program is offering tutoring and mentoring services for all STEM majors, particularly for students working through challenging gateway courses. The program includes career counseling, faculty mentoring, a recruitment component that involves consultation with student families, and a variety of financial incentives. The program also is designed to recruit students from historically underserved populations into STEM majors. The evaluation effort, led by an expert within the University, is using multi-phased, mixed methodology to monitor and improve the quality of the Center's activities and to measure the impact of the initiatives on students and faculty. Broader impacts include a special focus on historically underserved populations, enhancement of the University's infrastructure, and the dissemination of their best practices.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Albany
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-sponsored initiative [under the Division of Undergraduate Education Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Talent Expansion Program (STEP)] had as its primary goals the accomplishment of: (1) a 40% to 50% increase in the 4-year graduation rates of freshman with declared STEM majors; (2) a 50% increase in the number of STEM graduates from historically underserved populations; and (3) the institutionalization of CARSS. Broader impacts included development of strategies that would positively impact the performance of students from historically underserved populations and enhancement of the University's infrastructure. A salient feature of the CARSS program is the provision of free highly structured tutoring for students enrolled in STEM gateway courses in the areas of biology, chemistry and physics. Hired tutors provides supplemental instruction for groups comprised of no more than 10 tutees at a time. Tutees select and sign up for sessions through a dedicated website (www.albany.edu/carss). It is primarily through this mechanism that student retention in STEM majors and by extension, increases in graduation rates occurs.

All of the project goals were accomplished and the benchmarks outlined in the original proposal were either met or surpassed for program participants. With regard to institutionalization, the program: (1) is now permanent. It is operated from a dedicated 1,300 sq. ft. fully furnished space devoted to CARSS activities; (2) is fully funded by the University; (3) engineered a pipeline to provide a stream of highly trained supplemental instructors that lead learning communities in the courses for which CARSS offers tutoring. This occurs through a course (UUNI 498) that provides rigorous training for would-be tutors on how best to meet the needs of STEM majors in gateway courses.

A total of 750-800 learning community sessions are held per semester! CARSS currently offers tutoring in the following areas that include a total of 13 courses: General Chemistry I&II; General Physics I&II; General Physics I: Mechanics; General Physics II: Electromagnetism; Genetics; Organic Chemistry I&II; Physical Chemistry I; and Biophysical Chemistry. The program currently hires approximately 25 tutors per semester who offer >1000 hours of learning community tutoring, and >120 hours of exam review session time per term. Over 1000 unique STEM majors avail themselves of CARSS services per academic year.

We highlight here the impact of CARSS on the 4-year graduation and retention rates for students across several demographics: (A) As of fall 2012, (the fourth year for CARSS cohort 1), 16 out of 24 underrepresented minority students (67%) from the CARSS cohort, graduated in STEM, compared to 58 out of 241 (24%) for the baseline (two years prior to institution of the CARSS program) and 4 out of 37 (11%) for the control (students who could have but did not participate in CARSS programing). The data also show that the dropout rate for the control group is 65% for cohort 1, in contrast to only 17% observed for the CARSS cohort; (B) For female STEM majors, the graduation rates for the baseline and non-CARSS controls were 38 and 42% respectively, while that for the CARSS group was 66%. To meet the target set in the grant proposal, the CARSS graduation rate had to be greater than 55% (i.e. a 50% increase over the benchmark rate). CARSS cohort 1 surpassed the target compared to the benchmark by 11% and was 25% higher compared to the control group; (C) For Hispanic women, the graduation rates for the benchmark and non-CARSS controls were 28% and 11% respectively, while that for the CARSS group was 100%. To meet the target, the CARSS graduation rate had to be greater than 43% (i.e. a 50% increase over the benchmark years). CARSS cohort 1 surpassed the target compared to the benchmark by 57% ...

To meet the target, the CARSS graduation rate had to be greater than 43% (i.e. a 50% increase over the benchmark years).
